posts.name: William Xie
posts.cooked:
Not sure shifting swerve is in most teams‚Äô best interests‚Äìto echo what others have said in the past, BLDC motors are powerful enough to obviate the traction/acceleration trade-off problem of years past.

To answer you more directly, in modern times, 4265 ran shifting swerve (MK4 modified with a ball-shifter) to great success in 2021 and 2022.

In the past, my former team also found a lot of success with shifting swerve in 2017 . At its heart it was 221-style swerve with a COTS VexPro ball-shifter. Very similar to what 368 ran in 2014 . We really optimized the hell out of the width/height/weight of that style of module though, and I still have a soft-spot for the 221-style swerve. Unfortunately I think my CAD was lost to GrabCAD Workbench‚Äôs demise.

link_counts.title: FRC 4265 Secret City Wildbots Shifting Swerve CAD Release

posts.cooked: Team 5687 has a really nice custom shifting swerve design they have been utilizing this year after differential swerve was made illegal. You can find some information about it from their behind the bumpers video. This swerve allows them to reach insanely fast speeds. They speed past everyone.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôve built two of them for robots over the years.  These were in the days before brushless motors, and before the ubiquity of COTS swerves.  It wasn‚Äôt a great idea either year that we did it, and in my opinion, it is even less valuable now:

-Shifting swerve adds quite a bit of weight, size, and complexity, because it generally requires 4 shifters (one for each module).  With differential drive you generally only needed two (one for each side) -The brushless motors have so much power in them already that the added benefit of a shifter becomes minimized. -Building your own swerve instead of using a COTS one is a big expenditure of time -In the past, some teams used shifters in their drive gearbox to create Power Take Offs.  This is also less useful nowadays with the extra power ports on the Rev PDH .

So, if you are thinking about it for competitive reasons, I‚Äôd advise skipping it.  If you are doing it for fun/education/inspiration, then it is certainly a good project.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked: The last time we built a shifter gearbox was 2018, it was also a PTO for the climber (also with two speeds) and it was cool as heck, but I‚Äôm not sure we ever took it our of high gear, I can‚Äôt think of any reason you would now in the brushless era either.

posts.name: Maroon Golf
posts.cooked:
As swerve has become the standard and the limitations on drive motors has been implemented, I feel that as the barrier to entry to shifting swerve becomes lower, it could be used to throw a curve ball into the mix. I‚Äôm thinking of how clogged up the source gets with source focused defense and the usage of L4 gearing that was discussed last year to improve cycle times. It would be interesting to be able to evade defense, to overcome pushing/pinning matches, and still have that high top speed.  It could also help defensive focused swerve bots not get pushed into penalty zones, or those focused on testing a team‚Äôs wiring through cross traffic impacts.

I‚Äôm mostly interested in where it has been used and how successful it has been. I run a rookie team, and we couldn‚Äôt quite accomplish something like this without sending the cad out to be machined for us so it is not likely that we will be running something like this in the near future. But I can‚Äôt help but wonder what the next THING will be to gain a competitive advantage in the age of swerve.

posts.name: Maroon Golf
posts.cooked:
Seeing what 5687 and 2557 are doing makes me want to go down this road.  5687 highlighting the efforts of High Tide as their inspiration makes me think I am in the right school of thought here.  Maybe they never get ran in comp, I think the learning experience would be great if anything as many have mentioned.

As far as expendiature of resources, I will need to see whether or not it fits into our list of priorities as a team.  For now perfecting, and maintaining our current swerve chassis takes priority.

posts.name: Devin Slattery
posts.cooked:
We have run shifting swerves sense 2021 and there are benefits and downsides to it. It definitely helps with defense and prevents from being locked up/pinned. We haven‚Äôt been able to gear higher than some teams because we tend to build max weight robots and power draw has been our limiter but with a light robot much higher speeds are possible. Another downside is everything has to be manufactured and assembled in season which we have found to be challenging at times. All of our CAD files can be found within our 2022 , 2023 , 2024 CD posts

Weight and size: Our inverted modules weight 7.4 lbs per module vs MK4i‚Äôs 6.3 lbs. We sit slightly higher above the drive tube but the foot print is much larger sense we use a 5" pneumatic wheel instead of a smaller 4" wheel.

link_counts.title: 4265 Inverted Shifting Swerve v2 CAD Release
FRC 4265 Secret City Wildbots Shifting Swerve CAD Release

posts.name: Maroon Golf
posts.cooked: I am quite fond of this design. It makes sense that you might consider larger wheels, but can I ask why pneumatic wheels?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: How can you have any pudding if you don't eat your meat!

posts.custom_user_title: How can you have any pudding if you don't eat your meat!

posts.name: Devin Slattery
posts.cooked: We went for a pneumatic wheel to help with bumps in the field, mainly in 2020 with the steel beams on the ground. We have stuck with it ever since, but we are considering switching to a 4‚Äù, TPU 3D printed wheel if we find they are durable enough. We could only find 5‚Äù pneumatic wheels so that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs that large. The main limiter to the shifting swerve for us is wheel traction so looking at alternative wheels is going to be a high priority in the off-season for us.

posts.name: Maroon Golf
posts.cooked:
For grip, that 4" TPU seems like the way to go.  It would work well in pushing matches with your low gear.  I can‚Äôt remember which team put it out there, but there was CAD out there for it with a traction test to prove viability. I will edit and link later if I can dig it up.

Edit: linking this TPU90A mega thread for future reference TPU90A Grippy Tire CAD published (Finally)

posts.name: Devin Slattery
posts.cooked:
Over the offseason we printed a modified wheel using tj^2 design. We made it so our larger bevel gear would work with it and expanded it out to 5‚Äù. We briefly put it on our robot and didn‚Äôt have any problems with it. Overall, it showed promise but I‚Äôm curious what it does to the tread when you start pushing in a lower gear.
